title: Lippia graveolens
text:
Lippia graveolens, a species of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the verbena or vervain family, <a href="Verbenaceae">Verbenaceae</a>, is native to the <a href="southwestern%20United%20States">southwestern United States</a> (<a href="Texas">Texas</a> and southern <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>), <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, and <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> as far south as <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>. Common names include: Mexican oregano, redbrush lippia, ('wild oregano'), scented lippia, and scented matgrass. The <a href="Specific%20name%20%28botany%29">specific epithet</a> is derived from two <a href="Latin">Latin</a> words: , meaning 'heavy', and , meaning 'oil'. It is a <a href="shrub">shrub</a> or small <a href="tree">tree</a>, reaching in height. Fragrant white or yellowish <a href="flower">flower</a>s can be found on the plant throughout the year, especially after rains.
Uses.
The <a href="essential%20oil">essential oil</a> of "Lippia graveolens" contains 0-81% <a href="thymol">thymol</a>, 0-48% <a href="carvacrol">carvacrol</a>, 3-30% para-<a href="cymene">cymene</a>, and 0-15% <a href="eucalyptol">eucalyptol</a>. The first two components give the plant a flavor similar to <a href="oregano">oregano</a> (to which it is not closely related), and the leaves are widely used as an <a href="herb">herb</a> in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a>.
